journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part A: Journal of Power and Energy

title-group.article-title: Thermoelectric quadrupole of a leg to model transient state

article-meta.aff: 1Département FTC, CNRS-Université de Poitiers-ENSMA, Poitiers, France
2Laboratoire de Cristallographie et de Science des Matériaux, CRISMAT ENSICAEN, Caen, France
3Laboratoire d’Optimisation de la Conception et Ingénierie de l’Environnement, LOCIE ESIGEC, Le Bourget-Du-Lac, France
4Laboratoire de Physique des Matériaux, Ecole Nationale Supérieure des Mines de Nancy, Nancy, France

author-notes.corresp: *Institut PPrime, CNRS-Université de Poitiers-ENSMA, Département FTC, EnSIP, B25, Campus Sud, 2 rue Pierre Brousse, 86022 Poitiers, France. email: myriam.lazard@univ-poitiers.fr

abstract.p: The transient heat transfer in a thermoelectric leg is modelled. The Thomson effect is into account, whereas it is often neglected in other studies. Thanks to the expressions of the temperature and the heat flux expressed in the Laplace domain, a semi-analytical technique, the so-called quadrupole method is performed. No mesh is required. The whole matrix formulation is given for different initial conditions. It will allow, for instance, to evaluate easily the efficiency or the coefficient of performance of the thermoelement or use it as inverse method, for instance, to perform estimations.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Even if the basis and the principle of thermoelectric effects [1, 2] have been clearly and widely described in the past centuries, a significant part of research and development effort is still devoted to thermoelectricity in order to make it emerge as renewable energy. Vining [3] put the stress on the primary goal adopted at ICT 2007 by the International Thermoelectric Society: ‘to promote an understanding of the role thermoelectric technology may play in environmental impact and mitigating global climate change’. Many significant advances have been made concerning the discovery and the elaboration of thermoelectric materials with a high figure of merit z (the good candidates are among materials with low thermal conductivity λ but high electrical conductivity σ) [4]. However, the need for thermal modelling of thermoelectric element is still of prime importance, that is why many researchers [5–12] take interest in solving the heat transfer equation in order to obtain the temperature within the thermoelement and the heat flux. Indeed these two quantities are needed to determine the performance of the device by calculating the efficiency of the element or for instance by evaluating the coefficient of performance [5]. Most often steady state is investigated by numerical methods such as finite difference methods [6] or introducing intensive reduced quantities to reformulate the general equation for efficiency [7]. Many efforts have been made to investigate the transient case in order to study, for instance, the response of thermoelectric microcoolers [8–14]. Most often, approximations are made and the Thomson effect is neglected.

In this article, the complete one-dimensional transient heat transfer equation is solved semi-analytically in order to obtain explicit expressions of the temperature and also the heat flux. A quadrupole formulation of the problem taking the Thomson effect into account is then proposed.

sec.title: 2 EQUATIONS
sec.p:
Consider a single thermoelectric leg of length L and cross-sectional area A. An electrical current I=JA enters uniformly into the element (Fig. 1). The one-dimensional energy balance [2] that describes the thermal behaviour of the leg is the following partial differential equation (1) The temperature is a function of the spatial variable x and the time t. The relevant material properties are the density ρ, the heat capacity cp, the thermal conductivity λ, the electrical conductivity σ, and the Thomson coefficient τ. Fig. 1
Scheme of the thermoelectric leg

The Thomson effect is usually defined as reversible heat exchange between a conductor and its surroundings accompanying steady current flow [15]. The Thomson coefficient is then identical to the isobaric specific heat (Thomson’s specific heat of electricity).

In the steady-state case, the classical boundary conditions are the following ones: the hot side of the leg is at absolute temperature TH and the cold side at temperature TC. In this case, it is relatively easy to investigate the influence of the Thomson effect. Equation (1) becomes a classical ordinary differential equation. The temperature within the leg contains no quadratic terms but exponential terms and is then given by the following analytical expression (2)

Figure 2 illustrates the influence of Thomson effect on the temperature profile into a leg. More results on the influence of Thomson effect for steady-state case could be found, for instance, in references [16–19]. Chen et al. [17] investigated the influence of the Thomson effect on a thermoelectric generator and obtained relationships to express the maximum power output. Meng et al. [18] performed a numerical model to investigate a thermoelectric generator with heat exchangers by taking into account the Thomson coefficient. Du and Wen [19] chose a second-order linear Seebeck model which represents the Thomson coefficient as a second-order polynomial to analyse a one-stage thermoelectric cooler. As a consequence, the governing equation becomes a non-linear ordinary differential equation. However, all the previous articles focused on steady-state heat transfer which simplifies significantly the resolution of equation. Fig. 2
Influence of the Thomson effect on the temperature in a thermoelectric leg (Thomson coefficient from 1.04 e−8 to 2.6 e−3 V/K)
The influence on the heat flux and also the entropy is also investigated in reference [16].

However, for the transient case, it is a partial differential equation which must be solved and all the more complicated that a term is added when the Thomson effect is taken into account. Of course, classical numerical methods such as finite difference method [5] or finite element method [16] could be used. They are well adapted to direct simulations. However, it is also interesting to perform semi-analytical technique which could be used, for instance, to inverse data because semi-analytical form makes its implementation in a code more easy.

For the transient case, consider equation (1) written in a more synthetic way (3) where (4) (5) (6) The typical property used in transient case is the thermal diffusivity a, the initial temperature of the leg is T0.

To solve this partial differential equation, it is very convenient to apply the Laplace transform. It has the main advantage to transform the partial differential equation into an ordinary differential equation in the Laplace domain which is then easier to solve. It is then possible to have a semi-analytical expression of the solution.

Introduce p the Laplace variable and note
Equation (3) becomes (7) Also, the solution of equation (7) (procedure detailed in Appendix 1) is (8) where ϑ¯(x) is a particular solution of equation (7) (cf Appendix 2), and ξ1 and ξ2 are two constants.
It is interesting to have the expression of the heat flux going through the thermoelement in order to have a complete modelling of the heat transfer within the leg.

Now, express the heat flux which is a linear combination of the temperature and the derivative of the temperature (where α is the Seebeck coefficient) (9) Considering equations (8) and (9), the Laplace transform of the heat flux is (10)

sec.title: 3 QUADRUPOLE MODELLING
sec.p: From a mathematical point of view, the quadrupole method belongs to the class of analytical unified exact explicit method for solving linear partial differential equations in simple geometries. It relies on classical tools such as Laplace integral transforms (in time) or space integral transforms (Fourier for instance). Steady-state or transient problems could be treated in one- or multi-dimensional heat transfer.

This approach was first presented by Carslaw [20] for the conduction of heat in solids. A precise name was not given to this method first when used in engineering electrical applications; but as it refers to an equation with four scales or poles, it was naturally called quadrupole method. The treatment of heat problems could follow a similar way the modelling of electrical circuits once a boundary condition is known. The Laplace heat flux (respectively the Laplace temperature) is the analogue of the electrical current (respectively, the electrical potential). Then, the thermal solution can be expressed in terms of linear matrix relationships between transformed temperature flux vectors at the boundaries of the system. The intrinsic solutions obtained, thanks to this formulation, have a form which does not depend on these boundary conditions.

Quadrupole formulation has been and is still widely used and developed [21] to solve different and complex thermal problems such as heat transfer in multilayer [22] or coupled conductive radiative transient heat transfer in semi-transparent media with anisotropic scattering [23]. It is particularly well adapted to perform calculations quickly and be used, for instance, to inverse data in order to remote to thermophysical parameters such as, for instance, thermal diffusivity [24] or make estimations in real time in order to have an adaptative control of the cutting process [25].
To summarize, this method provides a transfer matrix for the medium that linearly links the input temperature–heat flux column vector at one side and the output vector at the other side.
Now determine the quadrupole corresponding to the case studied.
Thanks to equations (8) and (10) (11) (12) where (13) (14) (15) (16) The expressions of Up and Vp, which are dependent on the initial conditions, are given explicitly in Appendix 3.

Combining equations (11) and (12), the quadrupole formulation of the problem is directly given by (17) This equation allows, for instance, to obtain and represent the transient temperature in the thermoelectric leg when one side is submitted to a sudden temperature jump, as shown in Fig. 3. Fig. 3
Transient temperature in the thermoelectric leg obtained through quadrupole

sec.title: 4 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: The transient heat transfer equation in a thermoelectric leg is solved with a semi-analytical model. Not only the Joule effect but also the Thomson effect is taken into account, whereas it is often neglected in other studies. In that case, the equation to solve is more complicated due to the added term, including the Thomson coefficient and the derivative of the temperature.

The explicit expressions of the temperature and also the heat flux involving the Seebeck coefficient are given in the Laplace domain. Then, a matrix formulation called the quadrupole method is performed. Not only the case of a constant temperature as initial condition is considered but also the initial temperature within the leg could be linear or solution of the steady-state heat transfer equation. One possible application of this formulation could be easy calculation of the efficiency or the coefficient of performance of a thermoelectric device, investigation, and determination of best operating conditions or parameter estimation if the model is used to inverse data. For instance, this model could also be used to model the thermoelectric generator applied to diesel automotive heat recovery presented in reference [26].

sec.title: FUNDING
sec.p: This study is financed by CNRS in the framework of ‘Programme Interdisciplinaire Energie du CNRS’.

sec.title: Procedure of solution of equation (3)
sec.p: To solve the following second-order differential equation (18) the roots of the characteristic associate equation (Γ2-A·Γ-pa=0) must be found.
Their expressions are (19)

The solution of equation (18) is then the sum of the general solution of the homogenous equation associated to (18) and a particular solution of (18). As a consequence, the solution of equation (18) is (8) where ϑ¯(x) is a particular solution of equation (18) (cf Appendix 2) and ξ1 and ξ2 are two constants.

sec.title: Expressions of ϑ¯(x)
sec.p:
Three cases corresponding to different initial conditions are investigated to determine ϑ¯(x):
IC0: the initial temperature within the leg is constant T0(x,t=0)=T0, then it is obvious that
(20)
IC1: the initial temperature is linear T0(x,t=0)=a1x+a2 with a1=TH-TCL, a2=TC, then
(21)

If TC=TH=T0, IC1 is the same initial condition as IC0.
IC2: the initial temperature is the steady-state temperature given by equation (2), then
(22)
